gradient_descent package

Submodules

gradient_descent.main module

gradient_descent.main.main()

Run the gradient descent algorithm on the SIC-POVM problem.’

gradient_descent.main.target_function(x: ndarray) → float

Wrapper for G-matrix loss to define target function.

Does not enforce norm <= 1, but penalizes this with a large value of the loss. The reason for this is that scipy.optimize.minimize, even with constraints, sometimes evaluates the function just outside the specified boundaries.

Parameters:

x (np.ndarray of float) – the candidate array, should be of length 2*d - 2 where d is the dimensionality of the Hilbert space

Returns:

the loss

Return type:

(float)

gradient_descent.parameters module

class gradient_descent.parameters.Base(target_name: str, n_dims: int)

Bases: Parameters

Base class for storing parameters that are common for GD and DEVO.

__init__(target_name: str, n_dims: int)
property f_evals_max: int

The maximum number of evaluations of the target function allowed before the minimization will be aborted.

get_constraints()

Get constraints on the input variables to the target function.

Callable method instead of property to not be saved as a parameter.

property minimization_gtol: float

The minimization will stop when the norm of the gradient drops below this value.

property minimization_threshold: float

Threshold for considering the minimization a success.

The minimization will stop when the current smallest function value obtained drops below this threshold.

property n_dims: int
property seed: int

Random seed used to initilized the numpy random seed generator.

property target_name: str

The max number of different initial vectors will be tried before aborting.

gradient_descent.random_BFGS module

Functionality for running scipy.optimize.minimize with randomly initialized points in parameter space.

Current problem is that running on test function dark machines 2 gives warnings stating that Hessian matrix for updating the trial vector during optimization should be set to zero. Don’t know how to elegantly do this without effecting the results of SIC-POVM minimization, so it has been left as-is so far.

gradient_descent.random_BFGS.info_line(trial_i: int, target: TargetWrapper, p: GDParameters)
gradient_descent.random_BFGS.main()

Run the gradient descent algorithm on a test function.

Demonstrates the usage of the gradient descent functions on a test function.

gradient_descent.random_BFGS.plot_results(history: MinimizationHistory, parameters: GDParameters, path: str)
gradient_descent.random_BFGS.plot_title(p: GDParameters) → str
gradient_descent.random_BFGS.run(target_function: Callable, bounds: Tuple[float, float], parameters: GDParameters, path: Path) → MinimizationHistory

Run the gradient descent algorithm.

Uses scipy.optimize.minimize to minimize the target function for randomly initialized points in parameter space, stopping if the function value drops below a certain threshold. The results obtained during the minimization process are stored and returned.

Parameters:

  • target_function (Callable) – the function to be minimized

  • bounds (Tuple[float, float]) – the bounds (min, max) of the elements in the array passed as input to the target function, it is assumed that all elements have the same bounds

  • parameters (GDParameters) – the hyperparameters used for the optimization

  • path (Path) – directory in which logs and results will be saved

Returns:

the results obtained during the minimization

process

Return type:

(MinimizationHistory)
